BE11:15am

RBS 3Q results are weak against company consensus expectations reflecting a tough quarter, but do not impact the forward looking investment case which is based on capital returns which we see as on track. 3Q was impacted by a weak performance in Natwest Markets and a PPI charge of £0.9bn, which came in at the top end of wide range of £0.6-0.9bn. Despite these items which resulted in a loss, CT1 at 15.7% was slightly ahead of JPMe 15.6% and management are
reiterating the glide down towards 14% by 2021 which will be driven by
capital returns including special divs and buybacks in our view. Within the
results, NII was inline with expectations despite the 6bp decline in NIM but
other Income, Costs and impairments were worse relative to expectations. Of these items, we note that the £300m cost reduction guidance for 2019 is being reiterated which implies higher cost reduction in 4Q vs 3Q. Within the key
divisions UK PBB revenues were 2% above our expectations and Commercial banking was 1% below our expectations. Although consensus may need to
adjust lower by low single digits for Natwest Markets, this division only
contributes 7% of our Op profit forecast for 2021 with non-material impacts in prior years so we see the 3Q challenges as largely backward looking, with the recent recovery in swap rates as well as lowered probability of a No-deal
Brexit. Overall, RBS trades at 0.8x P/TNAV 2020E for RoNAV of 10% JPMe
with c£6.4bn of cash return (23% of market cap) including £3.5bn via
specials/buybacks by 2021 and we would view any pullback as an opportunity to increase exposure to domestic UK.

PBateman + the £3.4m site ebit + synergies etc

11:19 am
BE11:20am

Jefferies:

BE11:20am

While RBS finally pulled together a broadly in-line net interest income print and has
not changed guidance/outlook, the 44% QoQ decline in NatWest Markets revenue
and associated £2bn of RWA inflation in that segment smack of 'old RBS'. Our
underlying thesis on the name around capital return is intact with a 15.7% CET1
but the market's performance will put pressure on incoming management for further
restructuring. Shares on 0.9x TBV.
The surprise factor in RBS's Q3 is a deplorable result in NatWest Markets, where core
income fell 44% QoQ driven by the rates business. Management relate that "Rates
income was impacted due to elevated hedging costs caused by reduced liquidity and
wider bid-offer spreads, as the market experienced sustained curve flattening across
global fixed income market" and the problem is that the £184m of core income is
generated on a £348m cost base in that unit. Further, this business saw 7% QoQ
asset growth which inflated RWAs by £2.4bn and took ~20bps off group capital
(which is still strong with a CET1 of 15.7%).

BE11:20am

Impairments were higher than expected with a charge of 26bps albeit down 10%
QoQ and 11% YoY - management cite an additional charge in respect of increased
economic uncertainty and IFRS 9 modelling adjustments, which appears at first
glance not to be quantified.
Uncontroversial NIM performance - the NIM fell 5bps QoQ to 197bps with the
pressure exclusively attributed to "competitive pressure" - this produced a net
interest income performance in line with street expectations. Within mortgage, front
book spreads improved Q3 on Q2, in line with the conclusion reached in our recent
work (the UK NIM was 2.44% v our expectations for 2.45%).

A. M. @BE: won't be it be spun as 'but the gov't gets 62% of that'?
#REF! as a taxpayer I'd quite like some returned capital to the exchequer
11:21 am
BE11:21am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:21am

We expect the trading-led Ppop miss and lower capital print to drive the stock lower; however with underlying trends in-line with MSe and cost targets maintained, we leave our below-consensus 2020E estimates unchanged. We remain Equal-weight, trading on 0.7x TNAV for a 9% ROTE 2020E. Ppop miss driven by trading and higher costs. Adjusted Ppop was 9/12% below MSe/consensus, driven by a £120mn miss in Natwest Markets revenues, and 3% higher costs due to timing of costs savings. CET1 was 20bp lower than MSe, and RBS took £900mn PPI provisions at the higher end of its previously disclosed range. Loan loss provisions were also slightly higher due to a re-calibration of the IFRS9 model in credit cards in particular. TNAV was 272p, 1% below consensus. NII was inline with volume growth offsetting margin pressure. Banking NIM was down 5bp qoq to 1.97%, 4bp of which was driven by lower deposit margins (i.e. lower rates), and 1bp due to mortgage margin pressure. Mortgage front book spreads are above the 80-100bp range previously provided in Q2, and has allowed overall mortgage income to be up in the quarter. The stock of mortgages was up 1.8% qoq and the total loan book was up 3.2% yoy. Consensus remains too high on Non-interest income. Two-thirds of the consensus miss in non-interest income was driven by Natwest Markets (100% in the case of MSe). This was driven by rates, which made only £2mn revenues in the quarter. We think this is more of a one-off in nature, and hence we keep our estimates unchanged for 2020E. However we are already 4% below consensus in Non-Interest Income which we believe needs to come down. CET1 was 15.7% vs. MSe at 15.9%. RWAs were £2bn higher driven by markets, which should be rectified in coming quarters. RBS took a £900mn PPI charge in the quarter, at the higher end of the £600-900mn range provided in September, which was compensated by a £162mn provision release related to US RMBS. RBS's higher PPI charge has a negative read-across for Lloyds, we believe, and could reduce the latter's 2019E buyback expectations further.We leave our estimates broadly unchanged. Management has kept its £300mn cost cutting target for 2019E, and we also leave our 2020E Natwest markets revenues unchanged (£1.3bn vs. £1.4-1.6bn guidance). The stock is inexpensive on 0.7x TNAV for a 9% ROTE 2020E, however we retain our preference for Lloyds where we see better risk reward.

#REF! maybe a better PR move would be to do a £6.4bn buyback of government shares?

Results were a clear miss to consensus and exhibited flagging momentum.
Disappointing NWM performance was the key factor which in our view raises
doubts as to its medium term contribution. Unchanged future guidance is reassuring
but if current macro circumstances persist we would expect further
earnings downgrades for RBS and other UK banks. We are Neutral on RBS
and see dividends as the main shorter term attraction.

11:30 am

Here's Barclays:

BE11:30am

Post-3Q19, we cut earnings estimates substantially, retain our cautious stance and cut our Price Target to 150p. A revised strategy is on the way, which somewhat clouds the near-term outlook for earnings/growth, but, as it currently stands, we think Metro Bank is set to be loss making for the foreseeable future, given a challenging income outlook and structurally high costs.

A revised strategy is on the way: Alongside changing its chairman, Metro are working on a strategic update to be presented with FY19 results which is likely to include a rebasing lower of financial targets, a substantial slowdown in growth ambitions and greater focus on cost control, alongside strategic action on the balance sheet.

A challenged medium term operating outlook: We forecast -2% income growth in 2020, driven by sustained net interest margin pressure and modest loan growth (we model +1% in 2020) – and while we expect lower cost growth given likely slower investment, it's hard to see Metro Bank as anything but loss making in 2020 and beyond – we forecast 0.1%-1.4%-0.9% RoTE in 2019/2020/2021.

Irish HF guy Vernon Hill leaving is deja vu. Mind you, TD got him out of a hole in the US by buying the US bank he founded with the coin machines and lollypops in branch!

BE11:31am

(@Irish: yeah, thanks for that suggestion. I was throwing the laptop against the wall repeatedly in the hope that the kinetic energy released would charge the battery.)

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Metro needs to sell to grow: With Q3 total capital + MREL ratio at 22.6%, we estimate Metro can only fund c5% balance sheet growth before railing up against its 21.5% interim requirement (ignoring losses). This highlights a need to sell 'non-core' loans, which we estimate could boost the capital/MREL ratio by c400-500bp, freeing capacity to grow in the core franchise, and support a (lengthy) recovery in returns, albeit at a loss of near-term earnings. For more, see Metro: Expensive MREL relief, 2 Oct.

Another tough quarter: Q3 underlying loss before tax of £2.2m vs. BARCe +£5.5m driven by weak revenues, with NII down 7% q/q and NIM down 11bp q/q (deposit costs, treasury asset sales, mortgage sale). Deposits grew 4% q/q, although Metro did suffer £200m deposit outflows in Sep (indicated to have since abated)

Irish HF guy @nightingale20201, the long room is unique to an email and if you use another email to have a FT subscription you need another long room account. Standard really. In today's world if you have an email and a mobile number you are considered a person.
nightingale20201 yes...seems that a number of stocks have a uplift after their CEO depart/the announcement of their departure, ...look at ATOS
BE11:33am

And Jefferies, buying.

BE11:33am

Better costs and impairments offset slightly softer revenue than expected. MTRO has reported its Q3 19 results which reflected an underlying loss before tax of £2.2m compared with our expectations for a £10m loss. The delta to our estimates is explained by: 1) costs which came in at £99.7m v our £110m est as the bank executes on its cost transformation programme (operating costs rose 13% YoY and are expected to moderate in the remainder of the year); 2) credit expenses of £1.9m compare to our £2.7m estimate. Offsetting costs and impairments, both net interest income and fees together missed our estimates by c2.5% - YoY fee income growth was still up 56% YoY. The NIM of 1.50% which was 2bps shy of our estimates - the driver of the gap here looks to be deposit costs about 7bps higher than we modelled (at 84bps in Q3). Exhibit 1 shows a variance table to our estimates.

Capital strong with a CET1 ratio 16.2% in Q3 v 16.1% in Q2 19 (pro forma the loan book disposal). The capital result is solid and 10bps above our forecast and against a regulatory minimum of 10.6%. We estimate TBV/share of £8.9.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Franchise indicators show deposit growth QoQ, moderation of loans and increased account openings. On the deposit side, balances totaled £14.2bn at Q3, with £528m of growth in Q3 (see Exhibit 2). This growth reflected £213m of net outflows in September around the time of the messy execution of the senior non-preferred debt issuance - management claim deposit growth has returned to "business as usual". What is impressive is that retail customer deposits grew 14% (£796m QoQ) in Q3 to £6.4bn with the net outflows majoring on retail partnerships (-3% QoQ) and commercial (ex SMEs, -8% QoQ). Customer account growth accelerated to 106k in Q2 (v 93k in Q2). Loan balances were -1% QoQ and at £14.9bn were modestly below our expectations for £15.1bn. MTRO is clearly being prudent at managing its L/D ratio, currently at 105% (down from 109% at Q2) and which we believe will have to fall to a level of 73% by 2023 if the bank is to avoid equity raises and is not granted A-IRB methodology on its risk weighted assets in this time frame.

Irish HF guy I am still using a Dell Latitude E4300, 10 years old. Swapped out the HDD for a SDD 3 years ago, new lease of life. Bought a volume Office 2016 Professional for 1.75euro so all is good. No surprise with MSFT results, all that IT spend moving to Azure and office 365 monthly fees.

FY 2019 guidance for Astra’s sales has increased again, to “low to mid teens”

rebates/stocking for Tagrisso, Symbicort and others (and the tax rate seems
to be rising), but the broad geographic strength of the growth drivers
including Lynparza, Imfinzi and Fasenra should be taken well.
